elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of crystalline inorganic–organic hybrid materials that have demonstrated huge potential in gas separation due to their ultrahigh porosity, boundless chemical tunability, as well as surface functionality. Most gas separations realized in MOFs are under an equilibrium state and are dependent on the difference in thermodynamic affinities of gases to MOFs, whereas nonequilibrium separation such as kinetic and molecular sieving separation attracting growing attention in the past decade is achieved based on the difference in the size and diffusivity of gas molecules. In this perspective, we first discuss the pore size, temperature, and pressure effect on gas diffusion as well as nonequilibrium gas separation in MOFs. Second, we introduce current techniques reported to measure intracrystalline gas diffusivity. Third, we review recent progress in MOF-based nonequilibrium N2/O2 separation, CO2 capture, and hydrocarbon separation. In addition, we describe the hydrogen isotope separation based on kinetic quantum sieving in MOFs as a special scenario of kinetic gas separation. Lastly, we summarize general design strategies toward MOF-based nonequilibrium gas separation and propose several directions to advance the study in this exciting area.

elements.content: In this perspective, we focus on nonequilibrium gas separation relying on the difference in diffusion behavior of gases and summarize recent studies in conducting this kind of gas separation using metal−organic frameworks (MOFs). We also highlight general strategies toward MOFs suitable for this application and possible directions to improve the performance of MOF-based nonequilibrium gas separation.

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystal Engineering of Nanoporous Materials for Gas Storage and Separation

Introduction

Separation processes are important operations in the chemical industry, accounting for 10–15% of the U.S. total energy consumption (). Gas separation, such as olefin/paraffin separation and CO2 capture, is gaining increasing attention recently due to its profound impact on advanced manufacturing, clean energy, and environmental sustainability. The conventional gas separation technologies such as cryogenic distillation and absorption have the limitations of extensive energy consumption, large carbon footprint, and high operation cost. On the contrary, adsorption-based separation processes such as pressure swing adsorption (PSA), vacuum swing adsorption (VSA), and temperature swing adsorption (TSA) have been proposed as promising gas separation techniques due to their features of easy operation and low cost. One of the key components in adsorption-based gas separation processes is the adsorbent materials. Apart from conventional adsorbent materials such as silicates, zeolites and carbon molecular sieves, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), a type of crystalline porous materials composed of inorganic metal clusters and organic ligands, have been extensively studied over the past decade as potential adsorbent materials for adsorptive separation. Compared with aforementioned conventional adsorbent materials, the structure, pore environment, and pore size of MOFs can be more readily tuned by crystal engineering to cater to various needs of gas separation.

elements.content: The mechanisms of adsorptive separation can be roughly categorized into equilibrium separation, kinetic separation, and molecular sieving. In equilibrium separation, all components in gas mixtures can enter the pores of adsorbents, and separation is based on the relative thermodynamic affinities of gases to the adsorbents. A common strategy to realize equilibrium separations in MOFs is introducing strong interaction sites into the porous materials to enhance the framework affinity to certain component(s) of the gas mixture. For instance, uncoordinated open metal sites in MOFs are well-known for binding CO2 and olefins owing to their Lewis acidity. On the other hand, amine groups can form carbamic acid with CO2 and have been widely employed in MOFs for CO2 capture. A potential shortcoming of equilibrium separation employing strong interactions between gases and MOFs is that extra energy input will be required to desorb gases in order to regenerate MOFs.

elements.content: As for kinetic separation, adsorption is governed by the diffusivity of each gas component in porous materials, and hence selectivity is inherently transient. If the pore aperture size of an adsorbent is so narrow that one component (or several components) in the gas mixture cannot enter, the adsorption rate of such component(s) can be regarded as zero, and kinetic separation will evolve to steric separation, which is also called size-selective separation. It should be noted that occasionally the gas components, although smaller than the pore aperture size, still cannot diffuse into the MOFs. Instead of steric effects, this can be attributed to the extremely low diffusion kinetics of these gas molecules under cryogenic conditions used during gas sorption measurements (e.g., 77 K). This phenomenon has also been exploited for gas separation, which together with steric separation can be categorized as molecular sieving considering the inaccessibility of the pores to certain gas components under a sufficiently long period of time (e.g., the equilibrium time set for gas sorption measurements). Molecular sieving and kinetic separation can be summarized as nonequilibrium separation to distinguish them from thermodynamic equilibrium separation. Compared with equilibrium separation, activation of adsorbents in nonequilibrium separation can be more energy-efficient due to the absence of strong binding sites. Besides, study in nonequilibrium gas separation can provide useful information and profound insights for designing practical adsorptive gas separation processes considering that industrial PSA, VSA, and TSA processes are mainly operated under nonequilibrium conditions.

elements.content: Although kinetic separation using carbon molecular sieves (CMS) and zeolites has been well established, reports on MOFs for kinetic separation or molecular sieving are relatively fewer. In this perspective, we will first discuss the pore size, temperature, and pressure effect on gas diffusion as well as nonequilibrium gas separation in MOFs. After that, we will briefly introduce different techniques to measure the intracrystalline gas diffusivity. Next, we will highlight recent advances in MOFs showing potentials in nonequilibrium N2/O2 separation, CO2 capture, and hydrocarbon separation. Apart from traditional nonequilibrium gas separation, quantum kinetic separation based on the difference in the de Broglie wavelength of H2 isotopes will be discussed as a special extension of traditional kinetic separation. Last but not least, we will summarize general strategies to engineer MOFs suitable for nonequilibrium gas separation as well as possible directions to improve the performance of MOFs to satisfy the needs of these interesting and useful applications.

elements.content: Pore size reduction by crystal engineering of MOFs is of critical importance to achieve nonequilibrium separation. When the pore size of MOFs is sufficiently large, gas diffusion is unrestricted, and the diffusivity of each component roughly equals each other. In this case, the equilibrium gas adsorption selectivity can be defined as the ratio of the Henry’s constants of the gas components (S k = K 1/K 2). As the pore size reduces, gas diffusion becomes increasingly hindered by the confined space, and molecular diffusion will gradually evolve to Knudsen diffusion or surface diffusion, wherein diffusivities of different components become distinguishable because they are related to kinetic diameter and the molecular weight of gas components. In this case, both Henry’s constant K i and diffusivity D i will join together to determine the kinetic separation factor: S k = K 1 / K 2 D 1 / D 2 . It should be noted that sometimes the equilibrium adsorption selectivity will be reinforced by the kinetic effect, but in other cases the selectivity may be compromised by the gas diffusion behavior if the more adsorbable component diffuses much more slowly than the less adsorbable component.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Diffusion in Microporous MOFs

Pore Size, Temperature, and Pressure

Pore size reduction by crystal engineering of MOFs is of critical importance to achieve nonequilibrium separation. When the pore size of MOFs is sufficiently large, gas diffusion is unrestricted, and the diffusivity of each component roughly equals each other. In this case, the equilibrium gas adsorption selectivity can be defined as the ratio of the Henry's constants of the gas components (S k = K 1/K 2). As the pore size reduces, gas diffusion becomes increasingly hindered by the confined space, and molecular diffusion will gradually evolve to Knudsen diffusion or surface diffusion, wherein diffusivities of different components become distinguishable because they are related to kinetic diameter and the molecular weight of gas components. In this case, both Henry's constant K  i  and diffusivity D  i  will join together to determine the kinetic separation factor:       S   k   =   K   1   /   K   2       D   1   /   D   2       . It should be noted that sometimes the equilibrium adsorption selectivity will be reinforced by the kinetic effect, but in other cases the selectivity may be compromised by the gas diffusion behavior if the more adsorbable component diffuses much more slowly than the less adsorbable component.

elements.content: When the pore size reduces to a critical value so that the diffusion barriers generated thereof become too high for the crossing of some gas components, the other component(s) can be enriched in the internal cavity of adsorbents and molecular sieving separation will occur. The corresponding S k approaches infinity because the less adsorbed component has a diffusivity literally equaling zero. To this sense molecular sieving can be regarded as the ideal separation method. It should be noted that these diffusion barriers may not necessarily originate from a pore aperture smaller than the dimension of gas molecules. For instance, Mn­(HCO2)2 possesses channels with narrow necks of small diameter (3.64 Å) but larger than the size of Ar (3.4 Å) (a), which theoretically should allow the diffusion of Ar. Nevertheless, this MOF exhibits a negligible amount of Ar uptake at 77 K possibly due to the high diffusion barrier. Another point worth noting is that reducing pore size may also enhance the host–guest interactions due to increased overlapping of wall potential of the framework, which may affect the performance of equilibrium gas separation. In this perspective, we will not discuss these scenarios in detail to avoid redundancy with the existing reviews. Instead, we will focus on the effects on gas diffusional behaviors exerted by pore size reduction.

elements.content: Apart from the effect of pore size on gas diffusion, temperature and pressure can also affect the mobility of the gas molecules in microporous frameworks. On the one hand, gas diffusion is a process related to the energy provided by the environment (related to temperature) and the concentration gradient (related to pressure); on the other hand, framework structures of MOFs may change in response to the external stimuli such as variation of temperature and pressure, which will lead to the changes of diffusion barriers. These two aspects may convolute with each other to affect the gas diffusion, corresponding accessible pore volumes, and gas adsorption amount. For example, the uptakes of N2 and Ar in Mn­(HCO2)2 at about 140 K are significantly greater than those at 77 K as shown in b, which is opposite to the common trend that the gas adsorption amount decreases as temperature increases due to the weakened adsorbent–adsorbate affinity at elevated temperatures.

elements.content: MAF-2 (MAF = metal azolate frameworks) reported by Zhang et al. exhibits similar gas adsorption properties. Prepared from Cu­(NH3)2OH and 3,5-diethyl-1,2,4-triazole (Hetz), MAF-2 possesses an NbO network featuring large cavities (d = 9 Å) interconnected by eight hexagonal [Cu6(etz)6] rings whose apertures are dependent on the conformation and movement of pendent ethyl groups. Interestingly, the ring aperture of MAF-2 is too small to allow the permeation and adsorption of N2 into MAF-2 at 77 K, while at 195 K the aperture expands and allows the entrance of N2. Such a temperature-dependent gate-opening phenomenon can be ascribed to the activated motions of ethyl groups at elevated temperatures.

elements.content: Similarly, a porous coordination cage CuTEI synthesized from Cu­(NO3)2­·2.5H2O and 5-((triisopropylsilyl)­ethynyl)­isophthalic acid (TEI) reported by Zhao et al. shows a thermosensitive gating effect by which raising the temperature yields an increase in gas uptake under certain temperature ranges, suggesting the existence of kinetic barriers at those temperature ranges. Apart from raising the temperature, such kinetic barriers of CuTEI can also be overcome by increasing the gas pressure, which is demonstrated by its higher adsorption amount of H2 at 77 K and 60 bar than that at 87 K. These examples indicate that nonequilibrium separation may only be effective for specific gas diffusion behaviors regulated by corresponding temperature and pressure.

elements.content: As nonequilibrium gas separation is based on the difference in diffusion behavior of different gases, it is important to study gas diffusivities in MOFs to evaluate the feasibility of conducting nonequilibrium gas separation. Methods to measure gas diffusivities in MOFs can be roughly classified into two categories: microscopic methods and macroscopic methods. Microscopic methods need advanced instruments for tracking the movement of gas molecules or direct observation of concentration profiles of gas molecules in MOFs (normally using single crystals). One of such techniques is pulsed field gradient nuclear magnetic resonance (PFG-NMR), which is able to measure the displacement of gases in the system due to transport processes. Mean square displacement ⟨r 2(Δ)⟩ of gases during interval Δ can be calculated and self-diffusion coefficients defined by D s = ⟨r 2(Δ)⟩/(6Δ) can be determined. Self-diffusivities can also be obtained by another microscopic method called quasi-elastic neutron scattering (QENS) if gas molecules contain hydrogen whose scattering is essentially incoherent. Besides, transport diffusivities Dt relating a concentration gradient to the flux originated from this gradient (J = −D t ∇c) can be determined by QENS as well when molecules are deuterated with coherent scattering. Recently, the development of microimaging using interference microscopy (IFM) and infrared microscopy (IRM) enables the direct monitoring of guests in individual single crystals and records the concentration profiles of guests in the observation direction. These techniques can be used not only for the calculation of self-diffusivities and transport diffusivities from the concentration profiles, but also for the determination of the governing mass transfer mechanism of gas molecules diffusion into the crystals. Despite the powerful functions to obtain the gas diffusivities in MOFs, microscopic methods have limitations such as the requirement of high quality single crystals and sophisticated instruments, which are not easily available.

Techniques To Measure Gas Diffusivities in MOFs

As nonequilibrium gas separation is based on the difference in diffusion behavior of different gases, it is important to study gas diffusivities in MOFs to evaluate the feasibility of conducting nonequilibrium gas separation. Methods to measure gas diffusivities in MOFs can be roughly classified into two categories: microscopic methods and macroscopic methods. Microscopic methods need advanced instruments for tracking the movement of gas molecules or direct observation of concentration profiles of gas molecules in MOFs (normally using single crystals). One of such techniques is pulsed field gradient nuclear magnetic resonance (PFG-NMR), which is able to measure the displacement of gases in the system due to transport processes. Mean square displacement ⟨r 2(Δ)⟩ of gases during interval Δ can be calculated and self-diffusion coefficients defined by D s = ⟨r 2(Δ)⟩/(6Δ) can be determined. Self-diffusivities can also be obtained by another microscopic method called quasi-elastic neutron scattering (QENS) if gas molecules contain hydrogen whose scattering is essentially incoherent. Besides, transport diffusivities Dt  relating a concentration gradient to the flux originated from this gradient (J = -D  t ∇c) can be determined by QENS as well when molecules are deuterated with coherent scattering. Recently, the development of microimaging using interference microscopy (IFM) and infrared microscopy (IRM) enables the direct monitoring of guests in individual single crystals and records the concentration profiles of guests in the observation direction. These techniques can be used not only for the calculation of self-diffusivities and transport diffusivities from the concentration profiles, but also for the determination of the governing mass transfer mechanism of gas molecules diffusion into the crystals. Despite the powerful functions to obtain the gas diffusivities in MOFs, microscopic methods have limitations such as the requirement of high quality single crystals and sophisticated instruments, which are not easily available.

elements.content: Macroscopic methods such as the batch adsorption method, frequency response, and breakthrough experiments determine the gas diffusivity based on the overall gas adsorption behavior of bulk MOF powders. The batch adsorption method is a facile, well-developed, and most popular method that has been adopted to determine gas diffusivities in MOFs. By fitting the experimental adsorption kinetics data obtained from the gas sorption analyzer with established mathematical diffusional models based on the assumptions for calculation simplicity, the apparent gas diffusivities depending on the properties of porous adsorbents such as surface permeability and crystal dimensions can be obtained. It should be noted that batch adsorption reflects the macroscopic gas diffusion behaviors consisting of macropore diffusion, diffusion from the crystal surface into internal crystal structure, and intracrystalline diffusion. Macropore or interparticle resistance can be excluded if the uptake rate is independent of sample mass. In an intracrystalline diffusion dominant model, where an adsorbent at an initial concentration C 0 experiences a step change ΔC at r = R c and held constant from then on, the analytical solution is M t M ∞ = 1 − 6 π 2 ∑ n = 1 ∞ 1 n 2 exp ( − D n 2 π 2 t R c 2 ) where M t is mass uptake at time t, M ∞ is mass uptake at equilibrium, D is intracrystalline diffusivity, and R c is the radius of the crystallites. If the concentration in gas phase is not constant, which means the boundary conditions are not constant, the solution for the uptake becomes M t M ∞ = 1 − 6 ∑ n = 1 ∞ exp ( − D P n 2 t R c 2 ) 9 α 1 − α + ( 1 − α ) P n 2 where P n are the nonzero roots of tan ⁡ P n = 3 P n 3 + ( 1 α − 1 ) P n 2 and α is the fraction of the adsorbate added in the step which is finally taken up by the adsorbent. In the case of surface barrier model where the process of diffusion through the crystal surface is the rate-determining step of the whole adsorption process, the model can be described as M t M ∞ = 1 − exp ( − α 3 R c t ) where α is the surface permeability of the crystals. The governing mass transfer mechanism can be determined by comparing the degree of fitting of experimental data obtained by gas sorption analyzer with the fitted results of different diffusion models. For instance, Tanaka et al. engineered the size of ZIF-8 crystals and studied the size dependence of the diffusion of n-butanol inside the crystals. By fitting the fractional uptake curve with mathematical models, they found that uptake behavior of large crystals (88 μm) can be well described by intracrystalline diffusion model, while that of smaller crystals is better described by the surface resistance model. This result indicates that crystal downsizing can lead to increased portion of diffusion surface barrier in the overall mass transfer resistance.

elements.content: Frequency response (FR) is another widely adopted macroscopic technology for gas diffusion measurement. In typical FR experiments, one parameter of the adsorption system, such as volume, flow rate, concentration or pressure, will be perturbed sinusoidally, and another system parameter will respond periodically with a different phase lag and amplitude. The information from the perturbed parameter and responding parameter together with the frequency of perturbation help to extract gas diffusion information in the porous adsorbents, and the governing mass transfer mechanism can be further determined by comparing the FR data with predictions from mathematical models corresponding to different mechanisms. In a recent work, concentration swing FR (CSFR) is extended to study the CO2 diffusion in millimeter-scale Cu-BTC single crystals, indicating a micropore diffusion coefficient of 1.7 × 10–9 m2/s with little dependence on CO2 concentration from 0.1% to 10%.

The information from the perturbed parameter and responding parameter together with the frequency of perturbation help to extract gas diffusion information in the porous adsorbents, and the governing mass transfer mechanism can be further determined by comparing the FR data with predictions from mathematical models corresponding to different mechanisms. elements.content: Although there are several studies using breakthrough experiments (or column dynamics) to characterize the gas separation performance of MOFs, the reports of using breakthrough experiments to study the microcrystalline gas diffusivity are rather limited. By purging a packed bed of MOFs with mixture gas of helium and the gas of interest, one can obtain the single-component breakthrough curve of the selected gas. Fitting this breakthrough curve with the linear driving force (LDF) model will afford the mass transfer coefficient k related to macropore resistance, surface resistance, and micropore resistance. If macropore resistance and surface resistance are negligible compared with micropore resistance under selected experimental conditions, the microcrystalline gas diffusivity can be calculated by D c = kr c 2/15, where r c is the average size of crystals.
elements.clean_text: Although there are several studies using breakthrough experiments (or column dynamics) to characterize the gas separation performance of MOFs, the reports of using breakthrough experiments to study the microcrystalline gas diffusivity are rather limited. By purging a packed bed of MOFs with mixture gas of helium and the gas of interest, one can obtain the single-component breakthrough curve of the selected gas. Fitting this breakthrough curve with the linear driving force (LDF) model will afford the mass transfer coefficient k related to macropore resistance, surface resistance, and micropore resistance. If macropore resistance and surface resistance are negligible compared with micropore resistance under selected experimental conditions, the microcrystalline gas diffusivity can be calculated by D c = kr c 2/15, where r c is the average size of crystals.

elements.content: In this section, we will highlight the recent studies of MOFs with potential in nonequilibrium N2/O2 separation, CO2 capture, and hydrocarbon separation. Although some studies discussed herein conducted multicomponent gas sorption or breakthrough experiments to demonstrate nonequilibrium gas separation performance, it should be noted that other studies only suggest the potential of the MOFs in nonequilibrium gas separation according to the single component gas sorption results. However, testing temperature and framework rigidity of MOFs should be taken into consideration for such evaluations. On one hand, it is worth noting that gas diffusion behavior and corresponding nonequilibrium gas separation performance can be significantly affected by temperature. Therefore, the gas adsorption preference of MOFs determined by gas sorption studies under cryogenic conditions may not keep identical trends at ambient temperatures. On the other hand, the nonadsorbed gas in single component gas sorption experiments may coadsorb with other gas components in real gas separation processes, especially in flexible MOFs that can undergo phase transitions stimulated by sorption, temperature, and/or pressure. Such phase transitions may alter the pore aperture size of MOFs and the diffusion barrier of gas, leading to remarkably different gas uptake and gas separation performance of the MOFs. For instance, Schneemann et al. studied the coadsorption of CO2 and other adsorbates (N2, CH4, C2H6, C3H8) in a series of flexible pillared-layered MOFs denoted as [Zn2(fu-bdc)2(dabco)] n (fu-bdc = 2,5-funcitonalized-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate; dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]­octane). They found that in the presence of C2H6 and C3H8, the CO2 uptake is significantly higher than that measured in pure component sorption tests even though the partial pressure of CO2 is below the phase transition threshold. More detailed discussions about gas sorption in flexible MOFs can be found in relevant reviews.

elements.content: As one of the widely used chemical commodities in the world, O2 not only plays a crucial role in sustaining respiration of most life on Earth, but also has vast applications in areas such as medical and life support, synthetic chemistry, oxyacetylene welding, military usage, and oxy-fuel combustion in fossil-fuel power plants. Currently, industrial separation of O2 from air is mainly implemented by cryogenic distillation. This process can provide O2 in very high purity (>99%) but consumes considerable energy and capital cost. Zeolites or CMS based adsorptive separations used in industrial scale and portable medical devices are more energy efficient alternatives, though the purity of O2 obtained by this process is slightly lower (∼94%). Though kinetic N2/O2 separation using CMS and 4A zeolite has already been developed, few studies on kinetic separation of N2/O2 using MOFs have been reported. Mohideen and coauthors reported a Cu-based MOF in which N2 diffuses much slower than O2. Starting from benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (BTC) and Cu­(NO3)2­·3­(H2O), BTC undergoes selective monoesterification during reaction to obtain STAM-1 (St Andrews MOF-1) rather than the expected 3D CuBTC (aka HKUST-1), which was confirmed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, infrared spectroscopy, and solid-state NMR. Composed of a copper “paddle-wheel” connected by monoesterified ligands, STAM-1 contains hydrophilic channels lined by metal ions which are filled with H2O molecules as well as hydrophobic cavities lined only by organic functional groups (a,b). The hydrophilic channels lie along the crystallographic c-axis with pore apertures of ∼4 Å, while the hydrophobic chambers with pore apertures of similar size (∼4 Å) sit among hydrophilic channels (c). Interestingly, water in the pores can be removed upon heating at 393 K, after which only hydrophilic channels remain open for the adsorption of N2, N2O, and CO2. On the contrary, the interactions between polar molecules such as H2O and CH3OH and the hydrophilic pores are so strong that they can reverse the crystal structure change upon activation, which enables the access of H2O and CH3OH to the hydrophilic channels along with hydrophobic chambers. Moreover, the adsorption kinetics of O2 is significantly higher than that of N2, leading to an O2/N2 selectivity of 4. Though this value is lower than that of the best CMS used in industry (20), this proof-of-concept work opens a new door for developing porous adsorbents for kinetic N2/O2 separation.

Separation of N2 and O2 

Kinetic Separation of N2 and O2

elements.content: Considering the size difference between O2 (3.467 Å) and N2 (3.64 Å), molecular sieving is a promising method to separate N2 from O2, and a number of microporous MOFs have been proven effective for this application thanks to the pore size engineering. An early example is Mg3(NDC)3(DEF)4 (NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate, DEF = N,N-diethylformamide), which is composed of Mg3 units stacking orderly and NDC bridging the Mg-oxygen clusters to form a 3D network. One-dimensional channels defined by the Mg-containing secondary building units (SBUs) and NDC ligands extend along the (101) direction with DEF guests residing inside. Activation at 190 °C removed the DEF molecules and resulted in Mg3(NDC)3 with a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of about 190 m2 g–1 determined by O2 sorption tests. Interestingly, although Mg3(NDC)3 can adsorb H2 and O2 at 77 K, it cannot adsorb gases of a relatively larger molecular size such as N2 and CO, suggesting a possible molecular sieving effect that can be used in air separation. Another early example is CUK-1, a MOF prepared by Co­(II) source and an unsymmetrical ligand 2,4-pyridinedicarboxylate under hydrothermal conditions. X-ray crystallography showed that the distance between two walls in CUK-1 is 11.148 Å, and the corner-to-corner distance across the channels (Co2–Co2′) is 14.334 Å, indicating possible N2 uptake at 77 K due to wide pore dimensions (a,b). Nevertheless, gas adsorption analyses showed that CUK-1 preferentially adsorbs H2 and O2 over N2 (c) even though the crystallinity was confirmed to be the same after thermal activation, which suggests a molecular sieving effect under cryogenic conditions that can be used to separate N2 from O2. A follow up study showed that dehydration temperature has a critical influence on the gas adsorption performance, especially for O2 adsorption. The O2 adsorption at 87 K is very low when the dehydration temperature is less than 450 K but increases abruptly when the dehydration temperature is higher than 523 K (d). Moreover, after degassing at 573 K, CUK-1 exhibits an irreversible O2 adsorption isotherm at 87 K, which was attributed to the flexibility of the porous framework.

Molecular Sieving of N2 and O2 

Considering the size difference between O2 (3.467 Å) and N2 (3.64 Å), molecular sieving is a promising method to separate N2 from O2, and a number of microporous MOFs have been proven effective for this application thanks to the pore size engineering. An early example is Mg3(NDC)3(DEF)4 (NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate, DEF = N,N-diethylformamide), which is composed of Mg3 units stacking orderly and NDC bridging the Mg-oxygen clusters to form a 3D network. One-dimensional channels defined by the Mg-containing secondary building units (SBUs) and NDC ligands extend along the (101) direction with DEF guests residing inside. Activation at 190 °C removed the DEF molecules and resulted in Mg3(NDC)3 with a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of about 190 m2 g-1 determined by O2 sorption tests. Interestingly, although Mg3(NDC)3 can adsorb H2 and O2 at 77 K, it cannot adsorb gases of a relatively larger molecular size such as N2 and CO, suggesting a possible molecular sieving effect that can be used in air separation. Another early example is CUK-1, a MOF prepared by Co(II) source and an unsymmetrical ligand 2,4-pyridinedicarboxylate under hydrothermal conditions. X-ray crystallography showed that the distance between two walls in CUK-1 is 11.148 Å, and the corner-to-corner distance across the channels (Co2-Co2') is 14.334 Å, indicating possible N2 uptake at 77 K due to wide pore dimensions (a,b). A follow up study showed that dehydration temperature has a critical influence on the gas adsorption performance, especially for O2 adsorption. The O2 adsorption at 87 K is very low when the dehydration temperature is less than 450 K but increases abruptly when the dehydration temperature is higher than 523 K (d). elements.content: An effective strategy of pore size reduction in MOFs for molecular sieving is using bulky organic ligands to construct MOFs. For instance, Ma and coauthors reported PCN-13 constructed by Zn cations and 9,10-anthracenedicarboxylate with a crystal structure identical to that of MOF-5. No interpenetration of networks was observed in PCN-13 due to the bulkiness of the ligand. Gas sorption tests demonstrated that activated PCN-13 can selectively adsorb O2 and H2 but exclude N2 and CO, suggesting a pore opening between 3.46 and 3.64 Å matching well with the crystallography data (3.5 × 3.5 Å).

For instance, Ma and coauthors reported PCN-13 constructed by Zn cations and 9,10-anthracenedicarboxylate with a crystal structure identical to that of MOF-5. No interpenetration of networks was observed in PCN-13 due to the bulkiness of the ligand. elements.content: Another general strategy to reduce the pore size of MOFs is using longer ligands to render network interpenetrations. Cheon and Suh reported a 4-fold interpenetrated MOF, [[Ni­(cyclam)]2-mtb] n ­·8nH2O­·4nDMF, assembled from [Ni­(cyclam)]­[ClO4]2 and methanetetrabenzoic acid (H4MTB) (MTB = methanetetrabenzoate, cyclam = 1,4,8,11-tetraazacyclotetradecane). This MOF possesses 1D channels that are occupied by water and DMF guest molecules with an effective window size of 2.05 × 2.05 Å. After removal of guest molecules, it preferentially adsorbs H2 and O2 and excludes N2 and CH4, suggesting promising applications in air separation. Using similar strategies, Ma and coauthors reported a ytterbium MOF PCN-17, which is constructed from Yb­(III), 4,4′,4″-S-triazine-2,4,6-triyl tribenzoate and sulfate anions (). PCN-17 with a pore size around 3.5 Å features coordinatively linked double-interpenetrated (8,3)-nets based on Ln4(μ4-H2O) SBUs. Being stable up to 480 °C, PCN-17 selectively adsorbs H2 and O2 over N2 and CO (d), demonstrating potential applications in N2/O2 separation and H2/CO separation. Notably, PCN-17­(Er), PCN-17­(Dy), and PCN-17­(Y) that have the same structure with PCN-17­(Yb) but different lanthanide metal cations fail to show a molecular-sieving capability similar to that of PCN-17­(Yb), indicating the subtle role of metal cations in determining the pore size of MOFs.

elements.content: As the global warming situation intensifies, growing awareness of reducing CO2 emission associated with human activities has been aroused. In order to curb the atmospheric CO2 level, effective approaches are the capture, storage, and utilization of emitted CO2, where adsorbent materials with excellent CO2 selectivity and capacity are of crucial importance. There are mainly two approaches for CO2 capture from fuel combustion: precombustion CO2 capture and postcombustion CO2 capture. Precombustion CO2 capture refers to the CO2 capture from H2/CO2 mixture obtained by the conversion of hydrocarbon fuels such as biomass, coal, or natural gas, so that water will be the final product after H2 combustion. Postcombustion CO2 capture, on the other hand, stands for the process of CO2 capture from the flue gas (mainly N2) after direct combustion of fossil fuels. Different from precombustion CO2 capture which is conducted at high temperatures (above 200 °C) and high pressures (∼10 atm), postcombustion CO2 capture is operated at ambient temperatures (up to 60 °C) and ambient pressures. In addition to the aforementioned CO2 capture, natural gas upgrading conducted at high pressures is another application that requires CO2 separation from mixture gas, as raw natural gas contains CO2 concentrations higher than the allowed concentration (<2%) in natural gas delivered in commercial pipeline grids.
elements.clean_text:
Separation of CO2 from N2 or CH4 

Kinetic Separation of CO2 from N2 or CH4 

As the global warming situation intensifies, growing awareness of reducing CO2 emission associated with human activities has been aroused. In order to curb the atmospheric CO2 level, effective approaches are the capture, storage, and utilization of emitted CO2, where adsorbent materials with excellent CO2 selectivity and capacity are of crucial importance. There are mainly two approaches for CO2 capture from fuel combustion: precombustion CO2 capture and postcombustion CO2 capture. Precombustion CO2 capture refers to the CO2 capture from H2/CO2 mixture obtained by the conversion of hydrocarbon fuels such as biomass, coal, or natural gas, so that water will be the final product after H2 combustion. Postcombustion CO2 capture, on the other hand, stands for the process of CO2 capture from the flue gas (mainly N2) after direct combustion of fossil fuels. Different from precombustion CO2 capture which is conducted at high temperatures (above 200 °C) and high pressures (~10 atm), postcombustion CO2 capture is operated at ambient temperatures (up to 60 °C) and ambient pressures. In addition to the aforementioned CO2 capture, natural gas upgrading conducted at high pressures is another application that requires CO2 separation from mixture gas, as raw natural gas contains CO2 concentrations higher than the allowed concentration (<2%) in natural gas delivered in commercial pipeline grids.

elements.content: Industrial solution for CO2 capture is amine-scrubbing based on chemisorption between organic amine solutions (e.g., ethanolamine) and CO2, which is cost-intensive because of high energy input for amine regeneration and solvent loss due to degradation and evaporation. These problems may be alleviated or avoided by adsorptive CO2 capture using porous solid adsorbents, among which MOFs have been considered as one of the most promising candidates due to their tunable functionalities as well as pore dimensions. Most MOFs for CO2 capture (e.g., postcombustion CO2 capture and natural gas upgrading) take advantage of the strong binding between CO2 and uncoordinated metal sites or amino groups, which will unfavorably increase the energy required for the process of adsorbent activation and regeneration.

elements.content: Different from aforementioned equilibrium separation, [Cu2(bza)4(pyz)] n (bza = benzoic acid; pyz = pyrazine) is one early example that suggests possible kinetic separation of CO2 from N2 or CH4 (a). This MOF features two types of 1D channels with channel necks of 2 Å, one of which penetrates the crystal in the [110] direction while the other extends in the [11̅0] direction. Both channels lie parallel to the (001) crystal face and intersect with the (100) crystal face (b). This MOF was made into a single-crystal membrane and exhibited anisotropic gas permeation performance. Contrary to the impermeability of the (001) crystal face to most gases, the (100) crystal face is permeable to all gases being tested, among which the permeabilities of CO2 (1.5 × 10–12 mol m m–2 s–1 Pa–1), H2 (1.1 × 10–12 mol m m–2 s–1 Pa–1), and He (4.3 × 10–13 mol m m–2 s–1 Pa–1) outperform that of larger gases such as N2 (1.1 × 10–13 mol m m–2 s–1 Pa–1) and CH4 (5.9 × 10–14 mol m m–2 s–1 Pa–1) (c). Although it is difficult to extract information on adsorption kinetics, this report demonstrates the mobility difference of gases in the MOF membrane due to confined pore channels and provides guidance for designing novel porous adsorbents with small pore sizes for CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 separation.

elements.content: Bao and coauthors conducted a detailed study on adsorption equilibrium and kinetics of CO2 and CH4 in a Cu MOF Cu­(hfipbb)­(H2hfipbb)0.5 (H2hfipbb = 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene) bis­(benzoic acid)). In this MOF, Cu paddle-wheel units are connected by hfipbb ligands to form an undulated layered structure. The adjacent layers are bridged by monodentate H2hfipbb ligands to afford a 3D network, which interpenetrates with another identical network to afford the final structure with small cages (∼5.1 × 5.1 Å) along with a narrow window size (∼3.5 × 3.5 Å) (a). These dimensions are comparable to the kinetic diameters of CO2 and CH4, suggesting possible kinetic separation of CO2 and CH4 using this MOF. Indeed, aside from slightly stronger framework–adsorbate interaction of CO2 (zero-coverage heat of adsorption: 29.7 kJ mol–1) than that of CH4 (zero-coverage heat of adsorption: 21.4 kJ mol–1), CO2 molecules diffuse significantly faster than CH4 molecules and show a diffusion time constant of 2.97 × 10–3 s–1 (CO2) versus 1.14 × 10–4 s–1 (CH4), resulting in an overall CO2/CH4 selectivity (defined by S k = K 1 / K 2 D 1 / D 2 ) of 25 (b). This study not only suggests this Cu MOF adsorbent is promising for the CO2/CH4 separation, but also highlights the significant role that gas diffusion kinetics can play in affecting the performance of adsorbents and the importance of pore size engineering for adsorbent design.

The adjacent layers are bridged by monodentate H2hfipbb ligands to afford a 3D network, which interpenetrates with another identical network to afford the final structure with small cages (~5.1 × 5.1 Å) along with a narrow window size (~3.5 × 3.5 Å) (a). These dimensions are comparable to the kinetic diameters of CO2 and CH4, suggesting possible kinetic separation of CO2 and CH4 using this MOF. Indeed, aside from slightly stronger framework-adsorbate interaction of CO2 (zero-coverage heat of adsorption: 29.7 kJ mol-1) than that of CH4 (zero-coverage heat of adsorption: 21.4 kJ mol-1), CO2 molecules diffuse significantly faster than CH4 molecules and show a diffusion time constant of 2.97 × 10-3 s-1 (CO2) versus 1.14 × 10-4 s-1 (CH4), resulting in an overall CO2/CH4 selectivity (defined by       S   k   =   K   1   /   K   2       D   1   /   D   2       ) of 25 (b). This study not only suggests this Cu MOF adsorbent is promising for the CO2/CH4 separation, but also highlights the significant role that gas diffusion kinetics can play in affecting the performance of adsorbents and the importance of pore size engineering for adsorbent design.

elements.content: SIFSIX-3-Zn is another MOF constructed from short building blocks which is effective in kinetic separation of CO2 from N2 and CH4. It has a structure identical to that of SIFSIX-1-Cu except that the relatively long ligand 4,4′-bipyridine in SIFSIX-1-Cu is replaced by pyrazine in SIFSIX-3-Zn, and Cu­(II) is replaced with Zn­(II). The reduction in ligand length results in a contracted pore aperture of SIFSIX-3-Zn (3.84 Å) versus SIFSIX-1-Cu (9.54 Å), which not only enhances the interactions between CO2 and the MOFs affording high CO2 uptake (84 cm3 cm–3) comparable with that of Mg-MOF-74 (101 cm3 cm–3) at 0.1 bar and 298 K, but also provides sufficient diffusion barriers to differentiate the adsorption rates of CO2 and N2, which is proven by the evolution of fractional gas uptake over a certain period of adsorption time.

elements.content: When the pore size of MOFs is reduced below a threshold of about 3.6 Å, it is possible to selective adsorb CO2 while excluding N2 and CH4 as CO2 has a smaller kinetic diameter (3.3 Å) than that of N2 (3.64 Å) and CH4 (3.76 Å). It should be noted that MOFs for N2/O2 separation should have the potential for CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 separations as well because CO2 has a kinetic diameter smaller than that of O2, while CH4 is bulkier than N2. For instance, CUK-1 shows a CO2 uptake of 157 cm3 g–1 at 196 K but hardly adsorbs any CH4 at 186 K; [[Ni­(cyclam)]2-mtb] n exhibits a typical type I sorption isotherm for CO2 at 195 K, while the uptake of CH4 at the same temperature is negligible. Nevertheless, the MOFs suitable for size-selective CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 separation may not have a pore size large enough for the diffusion of O2 molecules to perform O2/N2 separation. To avoid repetition, MOFs for O2/N2 separation already mentioned above will not be discussed in detail in this section.
elements.clean_text:
Molecular Sieving To Separate CO2 from N2 or CH4 

When the pore size of MOFs is reduced below a threshold of about 3.6 Å, it is possible to selective adsorb CO2 while excluding N2 and CH4 as CO2 has a smaller kinetic diameter (3.3 Å) than that of N2 (3.64 Å) and CH4 (3.76 Å). It should be noted that MOFs for N2/O2 separation should have the potential for CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 separations as well because CO2 has a kinetic diameter smaller than that of O2, while CH4 is bulkier than N2. For instance, CUK-1 shows a CO2 uptake of 157 cm3 g-1 at 196 K but hardly adsorbs any CH4 at 186 K; [[Ni(cyclam)]2-mtb] n  exhibits a typical type I sorption isotherm for CO2 at 195 K, while the uptake of CH4 at the same temperature is negligible. Nevertheless, the MOFs suitable for size-selective CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 separation may not have a pore size large enough for the diffusion of O2 molecules to perform O2/N2 separation. To avoid repetition, MOFs for O2/N2 separation already mentioned above will not be discussed in detail in this section.

elements.content: The strategy of constructing interpenetrated MOFs for O2/N2 separation can be applied in CO2 separation from N2 and CH4. A triply interpenetrated microporous MOF Zn­(ADC)­(4,4′-bpe)0.5·xG (ADC = 4,4′-azobenzenedicarboxylate, 4,4′-bpe = trans-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene, G = guest molecules] with a primitive cubic net was prepared and characterized by Chen and coauthors. The interdigitated structure renders 1D channels with openings of 3.4 × 3.4 Å and 3.6 × 3.4 Å. Similarly, Cu­(FMA)­(4,4′-bpe)0.5 (FMA = fumaric acid) with a primitive cubic net has one less degree of interpenetration compared with Zn­(ADC)­(4,4′-bpe)·xG. The pore windows of Cu­(FMA)­(4,4′-bpe)0.5 are regulated to be 2.0 × 3.2 Å due to interpenetration, leading to H2 uptake as high as 91 cm3 g–1 along with N2 and Ar exclusion at 77 K. Notably, at 195 K, the adsorption of CO2 increases significantly at low pressure ranges, while the uptakes of CH4 and N2 exhibit an abrupt rising when the pressure reaches corresponding threshold values, which together with the desorption hysteresis of CH4 and N2 were attributed to the framework dynamics of the MOF.

The interdigitated structure renders 1D channels with openings of 3.4 × 3.4 Å and 3.6 × 3.4 Å. The pore windows of Cu(FMA)(4,4'-bpe)0.5 are regulated to be 2.0 × 3.2 Å due to interpenetration, leading to H2 uptake as high as 91 cm3 g-1 along with N2 and Ar exclusion at 77 K. elements.content: Apart from constructing interpenetrated MOFs, using shorter ligands (e.g., the distance between two coordination sites is less than the length of a benzene ring) is a straightforward strategy to reduce the pore size of resultant MOFs for molecular-sieving separation. A 3D microporous MOF [Cd2(tzc)2(H2O)2] n (tzc = tetrazolate-5-carboxylate) was synthesized from Cd­(OAc)2·4H2O and ethyl tetrazolate-5-carboxylate. After heating at 150 °C to remove the coordinated water molecules, the pore size of [Cd2(tzc)2] n was found to be 3.4 × 3.4 Å, which is suitable for postcombustion CO2 capture as it would theoretically accommodate CO2 molecules but reject N2. Indeed, the N2 uptake at 77 K is only about 4 cm3 g–1 when P/P0 equals to 0.95, while CO2 uptake at 196 K is about 53 cm3 g–1 at the same relative pressure. Recently, Chen and coauthors reported a series of MOFs consisting of quinolone-5-carboxylate (Qc) and several metal cations (Co, Ni, Zn, and Cu), among which Cu is the only one that reacts with Qc to form two supramolecular isomers Qc-5-Cu-dia (dia = 2-fold, 3D diamondoid network) and Qc-5-Cu-sql-α (sql = 2D square lattice network). Interestingly, Qc-5-Cu-sql-α underwent structural transformation upon desolvation, and the resultant Qc-5-Cu-sql-β has a smaller pore size (3.3 Å) compared with Qc-5-Cu-sql-α (3.8 Å) and Qc-5-Cu-dia (4.8 Å) (a). Such tuning of pore size gives Qc-5-Cu-sql-β an extremely high adsorption selectivity for CO2 over CH4 (S CM ≈ 3300) and N2 (S CN ≈ 40000) (b). The gas separation ability was further validated by molecular simulations and confirmed by dynamic breakthrough experiments, showing that Qc-5-Cu-sql-β is stable to moisture, and its separation performance is not affected by humidity (c).

elements.content: Opposite to the strategy of using smaller ligands, Bloch and coauthors reported a microporous Cu MOF [Cu­(bcppm)­H2O] constructed from an extended ligand bis­(4-(4-carboxyphenyl)-1H-pyrazolyl)­methane (H2bcppm) for kinetic gas separation. Single crystal X-ray crystallography shows that the 2D 44 nets composed of bcppm and Cu­(II) are interconnected via hydrogen bonding between hydrogen atoms of the water in one layer and the carbonyl oxygen atoms from an adjacent layer. Postsynthetic heating at 120 °C for 3 h stimulated a 2D-to-3D transformation of [Cu­(bcppm)­H2O], after which the limiting pore diameter of the MOF reduced to 3.6 Å (a,b), and the Cu­(II) centers changed from five coordinated to octahedral six coordinated with the water molecule from adjacent layers acting as the new ligand (c). The resultant 3D structure rejects N2 but can accommodate CO2 (d). Ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) calculation shows an ideal CO2/N2 selectivity of 590 at 293 K and 1 atm, which is remarkable given that no strong interaction sites are present in the MOFs and the CO2 heat of adsorption is only 29 kJ/mmol. This result suggests the potential application of this material in molecular sieving CO2 capture.

elements.content: Hydrocarbon separation is one of the most important chemical processes in the petrochemical industry, which is predominantly performed by cryogenic distillation. This process is highly energy and cost-intensive because most hydrocarbon mixtures, such as olefin/paraffin mixtures and hexane isomer mixtures, contain components with close boiling points and polarizability. In the past decades, there have been growing studies on hydrocarbon separations using MOFs, and several reviews on this topic have been published. We herein will focus on those studies based on kinetic separations.
elements.clean_text:
Separation of Hydrocarbons

Kinetic Separation of Hydrocarbons

Hydrocarbon separation is one of the most important chemical processes in the petrochemical industry, which is predominantly performed by cryogenic distillation. This process is highly energy and cost-intensive because most hydrocarbon mixtures, such as olefin/paraffin mixtures and hexane isomer mixtures, contain components with close boiling points and polarizability. In the past decades, there have been growing studies on hydrocarbon separations using MOFs, and several reviews on this topic have been published. We herein will focus on those studies based on kinetic separations.

elements.content: Among these studies, the separation of hexane isomers for enhanced octane numbers in gasoline is an interesting topic that has attracted considerable attention. Bárcia and coauthors reported the separation of hexane isomers using a 3D microporous MOF Zn­(BDC)­(dabco)0.5 (BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate). This MOF features three intersecting channels, one of which has an opening of 7.5 × 7.5 Å lying along the a-axis, and the rest two have openings of 3.8 × 4.7 Å and lie along b-axis and c-axis, respectively. Breakthrough experiments using binary mixed gas show that n-hexane can be readily separated from branched isomers such as 2,2′-dimethylbutane and 3-methylpentane, which can be attributed to the narrow MOF channels of 3.8 × 4.7 Å rejecting the branched isomers but allowing the accommodation of n-hexane. Reticular chemistry approach was successfully employed by Xue and coauthors to construct MOFs containing rare-earth metal cations (i.e., Eu3+, Tb3+, and Y3+) with restricted window apertures. 1,4-Naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-NDC) was used as the ligand, and 2-fluorobenzoic acid (2-FBA) was used as the modulator and structural directing agent during the MOF synthesis. The size of the windows accessible to octahedral and tetrahedral cages of the MOFs ranges from 2.4 to 4.0 Å depending on different orientations of 1,4-NDC. Owing to the limited pore apertures, hydrocarbons with large sizes have reduced diffusivities, suggesting possible kinetic separations.

elements.content: Lee and coauthors reported a series of isostructural and noncatenated Zn MOFs with metal-pillared-paddlewheel networks using 1,2,4,5-tetrakis­(carboxyphenyl)­benzene and trans-1,2-dipyridylethene struts with different bulkiness (a). These MOFs can be isolated as thin single crystallite plates with small dimensions along the directions of pillar ligands. As the surface area of top and bottom surfaces of the crystals are much larger than the combined area of the edge surfaces, the channels perpendicular to the top/bottom surfaces are the major paths for gas diffusion into the crystals (b). It was found that two of the MOFs, DBTO and BTO exhibit substantial potential in separating propane and propylene with kinetic selectivities above 10 (c), which was attributed to pore size reduction of channel I and II caused by Br moieties attached to the L1 ligand.

elements.content: Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) having topologies identical to that of zeolites are a subset of MOFs that are assembled by divalent metal cations (e.g., Zn2+ or Co2+) with imidazolate derivatives. Li and coauthors reported the first example of ZIFs for kinetic separation of propylene and propane. Three isostructural ZIFs, Zn­(2-cim)2 (2-cim = 2-chloro-imidazolate), Zn­(2-bim)2 (2-bim = 2-bromo-imidazolate), and Zn­(2-methylimidazolate)2 (ZIF-8) (a) were synthesized, and their C3H6 and C3H8 adsorption properties were characterized. Although ZIF-8 exhibits basically comparable uptake capacities of C3H6 and C3H8 under equilibrium conditions, the adsorption rate of C3H6 is significantly faster than that of C3H8 leading to a C3H6/C3H8 ratio of diffusion rate coefficients equal to 125 (b). Besides, Zn­(2-cim)2 shows similar kinetic selectivity and indicates a C3H6/C3H8 ratio of diffusion rate coefficients of 60. Although C3H6 and C3H8 have comparable molecular sizes, their diffusion activation energies are found to be 9.7 and 74.1 kJ mol–1, respectively. Such a difference in diffusional behaviors of C3H6 and C3H8 are believed to be controlled by the effective pore opening of the ZIFs. The molecular sieving properties of ZIF-8 were further investigated by estimating the thermodynamically corrected diffusivities of probe molecules with kinetic diameters ranging from 2.6 to 5.0 Å at 35 °C. Although the β-cage aperture of ZIF-8 is 3.4 Å based on the crystal structure, Zhang and coauthors proved that the effective aperture size, which was defined in the range where the slope of corrected diffusivity versus molecular diameter curve starts to drop, should be in the range of 4.0–4.2 Å as shown in c. Different from the sharp “cut-off” phenomena in zeolite 5A, C4 hydrocarbon molecules that are larger than this effective aperture size can still be accommodated by the pores due to the flexibility of the framework, leading to kinetic selectivities for iso-C4H8/iso-C4H10 of 180 and n-C4H10/iso-C4H10 of 2.5 × 106.

elements.content: Recently, Verploegh and coauthors used computational tools to measure the diffusivities of 15 different gases (kinetic diameters of 2.66–5.10 Å) in ZIF-8 with good agreement with the previous experimental studies. Dynamically corrected transition state theory (dcTST) and umbrella sampling combined with the 1D weighted histogram analysis method (WHAM) were employed to prove the vital significance of framework flexibility in the precise description of gas movements in ZIF-8. Pimentel and Lively further studied the feasibility of using ZIF-8 for kinetic separation of ethane, propane, propylene, and butane by experimental methods and computational models. On the basis of the separation factor defined for the gas phase S F = (y 1,e/y 2,e)­(y 1,f/y 2,f), where subscript 1 refers to the slower-diffusing component, y i,e and y i,f stand for the composition of the effluent and feed, respectively, they showed that the kinetic separation performance depended on the crystal size of ZIF-8, adsorbent mass, as well as temperature at which experiments were conducted. In the case of ethane/propane separation, the separation factor first increased and then declined as time evolved, indicating a transition from kinetic-control (ethane diffuses faster than propane) to equilibrium control separation (the propane-ZIF-8 interaction is stronger than that of ethane-ZIF-8).
elements.clean_text: Recently, Verploegh and coauthors used computational tools to measure the diffusivities of 15 different gases (kinetic diameters of 2.66-5.10 Å) in ZIF-8 with good agreement with the previous experimental studies. Dynamically corrected transition state theory (dcTST) and umbrella sampling combined with the 1D weighted histogram analysis method (WHAM) were employed to prove the vital significance of framework flexibility in the precise description of gas movements in ZIF-8. Pimentel and Lively further studied the feasibility of using ZIF-8 for kinetic separation of ethane, propane, propylene, and butane by experimental methods and computational models. On the basis of the separation factor defined for the gas phase S F = (y 1,e/y 2,e)(y 1,f/y 2,f), where subscript 1 refers to the slower-diffusing component, y  i,e and y  i,f stand for the composition of the effluent and feed, respectively, they showed that the kinetic separation performance depended on the crystal size of ZIF-8, adsorbent mass, as well as temperature at which experiments were conducted. In the case of ethane/propane separation, the separation factor first increased and then declined as time evolved, indicating a transition from kinetic-control (ethane diffuses faster than propane) to equilibrium control separation (the propane-ZIF-8 interaction is stronger than that of ethane-ZIF-8).

elements.content: Due to the promising gas separation obtained in ZIF-8, considerable efforts have been put on fabricating ZIF-8 polycrystalline membranes. According to the sorption-diffusion model, permeation (P) of a gas is determined by its solubility (S) and diffusivity (D) in the membrane as P = S × D. As propylene and propane have comparable solubility in ZIF-8, the dramatic difference in their gas diffusivities will lead to different gas permeabilities and promising gas separation performance in ZIF-8 membranes. Pan and coauthors used the hydrothermally seeded growth method to prepare a ZIF-8 membrane demonstrating a C3H6/C3H8 separation factor up to 50 and C3H6 permeability up to 200 barrers. In addition to the seeded growth method, other approaches such as in situ synthesis, interfacial microfluidic membrane processing (IMMP), and heteroepitaxially growing have been developed to fabricate ZIF-8 or ZIF-67 (a Co-based ZIF which is isostructural with ZIF-8) membranes with prominent gas separation performance.

elements.content: Currently, only a few studies of molecular-sieving hydrocarbon separation in MOFs have been reported. This is due to the close molecular size of the mixture components, such as C2H4 (4.163 Å)/C2H6 (4.443 Å) and C3H6 (4.678 Å)/C3H8 (4.3–5.118 Å). As for the separation of isomers of butane, pentane, and hexane, it is relatively efficient to separate the smaller linear components (n-C4H10, 4.687 Å; n-C5H12, 4.5 Å; n-C6H14, 4.3 Å) from the bulkier branched components (i-C4H10, 5.278 Å; i-C5H12, 5.0 Å; i-C6H14, 5.5 Å; 3-methylpentane, 5.5 Å; 2,2-dimethylbutane, 6.2 Å).
elements.clean_text:
Molecular Sieving of Hydrocarbons

Currently, only a few studies of molecular-sieving hydrocarbon separation in MOFs have been reported. This is due to the close molecular size of the mixture components, such as C2H4 (4.163 Å)/C2H6 (4.443 Å) and C3H6 (4.678 Å)/C3H8 (4.3-5.118 Å). As for the separation of isomers of butane, pentane, and hexane, it is relatively efficient to separate the smaller linear components (n-C4H10, 4.687 Å; n-C5H12, 4.5 Å; n-C6H14, 4.3 Å) from the bulkier branched components (i-C4H10, 5.278 Å; i-C5H12, 5.0 Å; i-C6H14, 5.5 Å; 3-methylpentane, 5.5 Å; 2,2-dimethylbutane, 6.2 Å).

elements.content: Chen and coauthors prepared a Zn-based MOF Zn­(BDC)­(4,4′-bipy)0.5 (MOF-508; BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, 4,4′-bipy = 4,4′-bipyridine) with the ability to transform reversibly from an open (a) to a dense (b) configuration. MOF-508a, the guest-filled version of MOF-508, is doubly interpenetrated and has pore channels with a cross section of approximately 4.0 × 4.0 Å. After guest removal, MOF-508a transformed to MOF-508b, and the volume per formula unit decreased by 16.7% to 342.3 Å3. A gas chromatographic separation study proved that MOF-508b can separate linear and branched isomers of pentane and hexane efficiently, which was attributed to the size-exclusion effect of the confined pore windows toward branched alkanes. Recently, Assen and coauthors employed isoreticular chemistry to design and prepare a new rare earth (RE) MOF with a suitable aperture size for size-selective separations of branched paraffins. The rational choice of fumarate to link the 12-connected Re hexanuclear clusters afforded a contracted triangular pore-window aperture of 4.7 Å, smaller than the size of branched paraffins such as isopentane (5.0 Å) and isobutene (5.278 Å). As a result, the RE MOFs exhibited unprecedented size cutoff selectivity toward linear paraffins rather than branched paraffins.

elements.content: In addition to separating hydrocarbon isomers, size-selective separation can also be applied in propylene/propane separation. In a recent study, Cadiau and coauthors reported a complete size-selective exclusion of propane from propylene at ambient conditions using a fluorinated ultramicroporous MOF, NbOFFIVE-1-Ni (also named as KAUST-7). Resembling the structure of SIFSIX-3-Ni, this chemically stable MOF is architected by bridging Ni­(II)-pyrazine square-grid layers with (NbOF5)2–. The subtle difference between the bulkier (NbOF5)2– in NbOFFIVE-1-Ni and (SiF6)2– in SIFSIX-3-Ni causes the hindrance preventing pyrazine moieties from free-rotating, affording isolated pore cavities with pore apertures as small as 3.047 Å versus 5.047 Å in SIFSIX-3-Ni (a,b). The restricted MOF window results in the selective molecular sieving of propane from propylene, which was evidenced by single-component gas adsorption analysis (c), calorimetric studies, and column breakthrough tests over 10 cycles (d). This study highlights the superiority of designing building blocks in MOFs for delicate tuning of aperture size for molecular-sieving gas separation.

elements.content: Aside from the aforementioned molecular sieving and kinetic gas separation whose performance is closely related to the pore size of MOFs, there is another special gas separation mechanism called kinetic quantum sieving (KQS), which was first reported by Beenakker and coauthors in 1995. It was proposed that isotope separation in microporous materials would be possible when the pore aperture (d) approaches the molecular size (σ) such that the difference (d–σ) is comparable to the de Broglie wavelength of the molecule (λ) (). For example, the heavier D2 has a shorter λ than H2 because λ is inversely proportional to particle weight. At extremely low temperatures (ca. 70 K) and in highly confined pore channels, this tiny difference between D2 and H2 will result in faster molecular diffusivities of D2 in the channels which will aid in separating D2 from H2. A more detailed theoretical explanation can be found in relevant literature reports.
elements.clean_text:
Kinetic Quantum Sieving

Aside from the aforementioned molecular sieving and kinetic gas separation whose performance is closely related to the pore size of MOFs, there is another special gas separation mechanism called kinetic quantum sieving (KQS), which was first reported by Beenakker and coauthors in 1995. It was proposed that isotope separation in microporous materials would be possible when the pore aperture (d) approaches the molecular size (σ) such that the difference (d-σ) is comparable to the de Broglie wavelength of the molecule (λ) (). For example, the heavier D2 has a shorter λ than H2 because λ is inversely proportional to particle weight. At extremely low temperatures (ca. 70 K) and in highly confined pore channels, this tiny difference between D2 and H2 will result in faster molecular diffusivities of D2 in the channels which will aid in separating D2 from H2. A more detailed theoretical explanation can be found in relevant literature reports.

elements.content: Despite a number of theoretical and experimental studies reporting zeolites and carbon nanotubes for separating hydrogen isotopes by KQS, there have been limited experimental works on MOFs for this application. The first MOF study reporting KQS phenomena was conducted by Chen and coauthors. The mixed Zn/Cu MOF Zn3(BDC)3­[Cu­(pyen)]­·(DMF)5­(H2O)5 (H2BDC = 1,4 benzenedicarboxylic acid; pyenH2 = 5-methyl-4-oxo-1,4-dihydro-pyridine-3-carbaldehyde) reported in this work has a 2D layered structure composed of Zn3(COO)6 connected by BDC ligands, with Cu­(pyen) pillars bridging adjacent layers to form a 3D network. Activation of the MOF results in a bimodal porous structure Zn3(BDC)3[Cu­(pyen)] (M′MOF 1) with a pore size smaller than 0.56 nm. H2 and D2 exhibit comparable uptakes in M′MOF 1 and isosteric heats of adsorption, indicating similar interactions with the frameworks and limited equilibrium gas separation selectivity. Nevertheless, gas adsorption kinetics study showed that the D2 adsorption kinetic constants are larger than that of H2, and D2 has slightly lower diffusion activation energy than that of H2.

Nevertheless, gas adsorption kinetics study showed that the D2 adsorption kinetic constants are larger than that of H2, and D2 has slightly lower diffusion activation energy than that of H2.

elements.content: H2 and D2 adsorption in [Cu­(4,4′-bipyridine)2­(CF3SO3)2] (CuBOTF) was studied by Noguchi and coauthors. Two kinds of 1D channels were identified in CuBOTF by synchrotron X-ray powder diffraction. One channel has a pore aperture of 8.7 × 8.7 Å, while the other one has a pore aperture of 2.0 × 2.0 Å, which is inaccessible to H2 and D2. The IAST D2/H2 selectivity of 1.3 obtained from experimental data at 77 K is in good agreement with the simulated result, but the experimental IAST selectivity at 40 K is higher than the simulated values, which was attributed to the faster diffusion kinetics of D2 caused by a quantum effect.

One channel has a pore aperture of 8.7 × 8.7 Å, while the other one has a pore aperture of 2.0 × 2.0 Å, which is inaccessible to H2 and D2. The IAST D2/H2 selectivity of 1.3 obtained from experimental data at 77 K is in good agreement with the simulated result, but the experimental IAST selectivity at 40 K is higher than the simulated values, which was attributed to the faster diffusion kinetics of D2 caused by a quantum effect.

elements.content: Another MOF [Zn5Cl4(BBTA)3]­·3DMF (MFU-4; H2BBTA = 1H,5H-benzo­(1,2-d:4,5-d′)­bistriazole) was exploited by Teufel and coauthors for the separation of hydrogen isotopes based on KQS. MFU-4 is architected from (Zn5Cl4)6+ SBU interconnected by BBTA ligands, possessing two types of cavities arranged alternately, which are isolated by small windows as narrow as 2.52 Å gated by four Cl atoms (a). The extremely restricted apertures form an energy barrier for gas diffusion, making classical diffusion impossible if the framework is perfectly rigid. Theoretical study and advanced cryogenic thermal desorption spectroscopy (ACTDS) indicated that the gas diffusion can be facilitated at elevated temperatures as the small change of framework structure and corresponding aperture opening can be triggered by environmental energy input. Nevertheless, when the temperature is so low that such barrier cannot be overcome completely, D2 has an advantage to penetrate through the gates due to its smaller effective size, leading to a high D2/H2 selectivity (up to 7.5 at 60 K and 10 mbar after 15 min of gas mixture exposure without achieving equilibrium, c). At prolonged adsorption time, however, D2/H2 selectivity will decline because gas adsorption evolves toward the equilibrium state, which indicates that the difference in diffusivities of H2 and D2 can facilitate D2/H2 adsorption selectivity.

elements.content: In this perspective, we discuss the relationship between gas diffusion in porous materials and nonequilibrium gas separation, review current technologies in the measurement of intracrystalline gas diffusivity, and highlight recent progress in MOF-based nonequilibrium gas separation. To realize gas separation based on this mechanism, pore size engineering of MOFs would be essential to either selectively exclude gas components in the mixture or generate energy barriers to discriminate gases with various diffusivities. Straightforward design strategies toward MOFs for these sorts of gas separations include using ligands with small dimensions to reduce the pore size, utilizing bulky ligands to hamper the diffusion of gases, and using postsynthetic modification methods to introduce covalently connected bulky groups into the MOFs. Besides, employment of long ligands may result in interpenetrated MOFs with small aperture sizes favorable for nonequilibrium gas separation, and starting from ligands with multiple coordination sites may end up with MOFs with small pores as well. In the case of ionic MOFs, introduction of bulky ions such as quaternary ammonium cations by exchanging methods would be an effective approach to tune the pore size. Apart from reducing the pore size to introduce the gas diffusion barriers, another method is to introduce hydrogen bondings between adsorbents and adsorbates to hamper the diffusion of adsorbates into the internal pores of adsorbents. For instance, He et al. reported that MAF-X8 prepared from 4-(3,5-dimethylpyrazol-4-yl)­benzoic acid (H2mpba) exhibits kinetic adsorption selectivity toward 2-chlorophenol over toluene. This is because 2-chlorophenol can form a strong hydrogen bond with the uncoordinated oxygen on the crystal surface and hence block the entrance of the 1D channels of the framework. Recently, Li and coauthors obtained a CMS by pyrolyzing a MOF precursor CD-MOF-2 and used it to separate C4–5 paraffins and isoparaffins. This work suggests a new approach to obtain functional CMS for kinetic gas separation based on rationally designed microporous MOF materials.
elements.clean_text:
Summary and Perspectives

In this perspective, we discuss the relationship between gas diffusion in porous materials and nonequilibrium gas separation, review current technologies in the measurement of intracrystalline gas diffusivity, and highlight recent progress in MOF-based nonequilibrium gas separation. To realize gas separation based on this mechanism, pore size engineering of MOFs would be essential to either selectively exclude gas components in the mixture or generate energy barriers to discriminate gases with various diffusivities. Straightforward design strategies toward MOFs for these sorts of gas separations include using ligands with small dimensions to reduce the pore size, utilizing bulky ligands to hamper the diffusion of gases, and using postsynthetic modification methods to introduce covalently connected bulky groups into the MOFs. Besides, employment of long ligands may result in interpenetrated MOFs with small aperture sizes favorable for nonequilibrium gas separation, and starting from ligands with multiple coordination sites may end up with MOFs with small pores as well. In the case of ionic MOFs, introduction of bulky ions such as quaternary ammonium cations by exchanging methods would be an effective approach to tune the pore size. Apart from reducing the pore size to introduce the gas diffusion barriers, another method is to introduce hydrogen bondings between adsorbents and adsorbates to hamper the diffusion of adsorbates into the internal pores of adsorbents. For instance, He et al. reported that MAF-X8 prepared from 4-(3,5-dimethylpyrazol-4-yl)benzoic acid (H2mpba) exhibits kinetic adsorption selectivity toward 2-chlorophenol over toluene. This is because 2-chlorophenol can form a strong hydrogen bond with the uncoordinated oxygen on the crystal surface and hence block the entrance of the 1D channels of the framework. Recently, Li and coauthors obtained a CMS by pyrolyzing a MOF precursor CD-MOF-2 and used it to separate C4-5 paraffins and isoparaffins. This work suggests a new approach to obtain functional CMS for kinetic gas separation based on rationally designed microporous MOF materials.

elements.content: Although nonequilibrium gas separation is expected to consume less energy in the process of adsorbent regeneration and activation than equilibrium gas separation due to the absence of strong interaction sites with adsorbates, one potential limitation of this type of separation is the limited gas adsorption capacity due to the lack of strong adsorbent affinity to the adsorbate or compromise of pore volume as a result of reduced pore size. For example, KAUST-7, the MOF that can separate C3H6 and C3H8 by molecular sieving, exhibits a limited C3H6 uptake of ∼1.43 mmol g–1 at 298 K and 1 bar, much smaller than that of 13X zeolite (∼2.6 mmol g–1 at 303 K and 1 bar) and Fe-MOF-74 (6.8 mmol g–1 at 313 K and 1 bar). Such limited gas uptakes may unfavorably increase the working cycles in TSA or PSA processes leading to increased capital and operational costs. Therefore, it is important to balance between reducing adsorbent activation energy and increasing gas adsorption capacity in future studies. A possible solution, for instance, would be to design MOFs that contain cages with large cavities but small pore windows so that the internal cavities provide space for gas adsorption, while the pore windows provide the diffusion barriers for kinetic sieving.
elements.clean_text: Although nonequilibrium gas separation is expected to consume less energy in the process of adsorbent regeneration and activation than equilibrium gas separation due to the absence of strong interaction sites with adsorbates, one potential limitation of this type of separation is the limited gas adsorption capacity due to the lack of strong adsorbent affinity to the adsorbate or compromise of pore volume as a result of reduced pore size. For example, KAUST-7, the MOF that can separate C3H6 and C3H8 by molecular sieving, exhibits a limited C3H6 uptake of ~1.43 mmol g-1 at 298 K and 1 bar, much smaller than that of 13X zeolite (~2.6 mmol g-1 at 303 K and 1 bar) and Fe-MOF-74 (6.8 mmol g-1 at 313 K and 1 bar). Such limited gas uptakes may unfavorably increase the working cycles in TSA or PSA processes leading to increased capital and operational costs. Therefore, it is important to balance between reducing adsorbent activation energy and increasing gas adsorption capacity in future studies. A possible solution, for instance, would be to design MOFs that contain cages with large cavities but small pore windows so that the internal cavities provide space for gas adsorption, while the pore windows provide the diffusion barriers for kinetic sieving.

elements.content: In addition, considering that most MOFs for nonequilibrium gas separation have rigid structures and constant pore size distribution, it would be interesting to design flexible MOFs whose pore size can change according to environmental stimuli such as heat and light so that they can be used to kinetically separate different gases of a wide range of molecular size. For instance, a class of MOFs called mesh adjustable molecular sieve (MAMS) prepared by Ma and coauthors exhibit varying gating effects at different temperatures. These MOFs have a graphite-type 2D layered structure containing hydrophobic chambers and hydrophilic channels. Owing to the dynamic tert-butyl groups gating between the hydrophobic chambers and hydrophilic channels, these MOFs can separate different gas pairs at different temperatures. Very recently, MAMS-1 has been exfoliated into nanosheets and reassembled into ultrathin gas separation membranes exhibiting an unprecedented reversed thermo-switchable molecular sieving effect. In addition, there are studies reporting MOFs containing azo bonds exhibiting different gas adsorption or separation properties due to the isomerism of azo bonds upon irradiation under different light wavelengths. These works encourage the design of “smart” MOFs whose structure can be regulated by external stimuli to cater to various demands of kinetic gas separations.

For instance, a class of MOFs called mesh adjustable molecular sieve (MAMS) prepared by Ma and coauthors exhibit varying gating effects at different temperatures. These MOFs have a graphite-type 2D layered structure containing hydrophobic chambers and hydrophilic channels. Owing to the dynamic tert-butyl groups gating between the hydrophobic chambers and hydrophilic channels, these MOFs can separate different gas pairs at different temperatures. Very recently, MAMS-1 has been exfoliated into nanosheets and reassembled into ultrathin gas separation membranes exhibiting an unprecedented reversed thermo-switchable molecular sieving effect. In addition, there are studies reporting MOFs containing azo bonds exhibiting different gas adsorption or separation properties due to the isomerism of azo bonds upon irradiation under different light wavelengths. elements.content: In summary, MOFs for kinetic and molecular sieving gas separation have already demonstrated promising separation performance. Future work includes improvement in working capacity, selectivity, and process development. We are looking forward to more efforts from the MOF community being put into this exciting area and practical applications of nonequilibrium gas separation using MOFs in the near future.
